active_tasks.title: Rewrite Templates for Old Connections
steps: Review current templates being used for old connections
Analyze response rates and effectiveness of existing templates
Research best practices for re-engagement messaging
Identify different categories of old connections (dormant clients, past colleagues, inactive students, etc.)
Create customized templates for each category
Incorporate personalization variables
Draft subject lines that increase open rates
Write compelling body content that provides value
Include clear call-to-action
Test templates with small sample group
Gather feedback and refine
Create template library with usage guidelines
Document when and how to use each template
resources: Analytics on previous outreach campaign performance
A/B testing results from previous campaigns
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by auditing all existing templates used for reconnecting with old connections. Analyze their performance metrics including open rates, response rates, and conversion rates to identify what's working and what isn't. Review the language, tone, length, and structure of current templates. Research current best practices for re-engagement communication, focusing on personalization, value-driven content, and authentic relationship building. Segment your old connections into meaningful categories such as: former clients/customers, past professional colleagues, dormant network connections, alumni, inactive students or program participants, and cold leads who showed initial interest. For each category, create 2-3 template variations that can be personalized based on specific circumstances. Key elements for effective reconnection templates include: personalized opening that references specific shared history or connection point, acknowledgment of time passed without being apologetic, genuine reason for reaching out (not just "checking in"), value proposition or offering (helpful resource, relevant opportunity, interesting information), open-ended question to encourage response, and clear but low-pressure call-to-action. Subject lines should be concise, personal, and intriguing without being clickbait (examples: "Quick question about [specific topic]", "Thought of you when I saw [relevant news]", "[Shared connection] suggested I reach out"). Keep email body concise (150-250 words maximum), focus on the recipient's interests rather than your agenda, and make it easy to respond with a simple yes/no or short answer question. Include personalization variables such as [First Name], [Company], [Last Interaction Date], [Shared Interest/Project], [Mutual Connection] that must be filled in for each message. Create usage guidelines that specify which template to use in which scenario, how much to customize beyond the template, optimal timing for sending, and appropriate follow-up sequences. Test new templates with a small sample of each connection category, measure results, gather any direct feedback, and refine based on data. Organize final templates in an easily accessible library with clear labeling and instructions for use.

Review current templates being used for old connections

Research best practices for re-engagement messaging
Identify different categories of old connections (dormant clients, past colleagues, inactive students, etc.)

Draft subject lines that increase open rates
Write compelling body content that provides value
Include clear call-to-action

Document when and how to use each template

- Professional copywriting resources

active_tasks.title: Write About Employee Schedule Changes
steps: Gather information about all pending schedule changes
Identify affected employees and their current schedules
Determine reasons for schedule changes
Calculate effective dates for changes
Draft clear communication about changes for each employee
Include all necessary details: old schedule, new schedule, effective date, reason
Review organizational policies on schedule change notifications
Prepare documentation for HR/administrative records
Create updated schedule charts or calendars
Send individual notifications to affected employees
Update centralized schedule database or calendar
Communicate changes to relevant team members
Address questions or concerns from affected employees
Confirm receipt and understanding from all parties
resources: HR policies on scheduling and notifications
active_tasks.instructions: Start by compiling a comprehensive list of all approved schedule changes including employee name, current schedule, new schedule, effective date, and reason for change. Verify that all changes have been properly approved through the appropriate channels (manager approval, HR review, employee agreement). For each employee affected by a schedule change, prepare a personalized written notification that includes: acknowledgment of their schedule change request or explanation of business-driven change, clear statement of current schedule with specific days and times, detailed new schedule with specific days and times, exact effective date when new schedule begins, reason for the change (employee request, business needs, project requirements, etc.), any impact on compensation or benefits if applicable, next steps or actions required from the employee, and contact information for questions. Ensure your communication tone is professional, clear, and empathetic, especially for business-driven changes that may not align with employee preferences. Draft messages in a consistent format for easy reading and comprehension. For schedule reductions or unfavorable changes, include supportive language and information about any available options or resources. Create or update visual schedule representations such as shift calendars, coverage charts, or team schedules showing the new arrangements. Before sending notifications, verify all information is accurate including dates, times, and names. Send individual notifications via appropriate channels (email, formal letter, or in-person meeting depending on significance of change and company culture). Document all communications in employee files for HR records and future reference. Update all centralized scheduling systems including shared calendars, time-tracking software, shift management tools, and any public-facing schedules. Notify managers, team leads, and colleagues who work closely with affected employees so they're aware of the changes. Be prepared to answer questions about the changes including clarifications on details, addressing concerns about impact, explaining the decision-making process, and discussing any flexibility or alternatives available. Follow up with each affected employee to confirm they understand their new schedule and have no outstanding questions. Set calendar reminders for the effective dates of changes to verify smooth transitions.

active_tasks.title: Issue New Job Sites Lines
steps: Review current job site postings and active listings
Identify which positions need new or updated job posting lines
Gather requirements and specifications for each position
Research effective job posting language and keywords for each role
Draft compelling job titles that attract qualified candidates
Write clear, concise job description lines/bullet points
Include key responsibilities, qualifications, and benefits
Optimize language for searchability and applicant tracking systems (ATS)
Ensure compliance with employment regulations and non-discriminatory language
Review and refine all job posting content
Format job lines according to each platform's requirements
Get necessary approvals from hiring managers or HR
Post to designated job sites and platforms
Track posting performance and adjust as needed
resources: Job site platform accounts (LinkedIn Jobs, Indeed, Glassdoor, etc.)
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by identifying all open positions that need job site postings or updates to existing postings. For each position, gather complete information including job title, department, reporting structure, primary responsibilities, required qualifications, preferred qualifications, compensation range, benefits package, work location/remote options, and employment type (full-time, part-time, contract). Research current market standards for similar positions to ensure your job titles and descriptions are competitive and attractive. Look at successful postings from competitors and industry leaders for inspiration on structure and language. Draft attention-grabbing job titles that are both accurate and searchable - avoid internal jargon or overly creative titles that candidates won't search for. Create compelling opening lines that immediately communicate the role's value proposition and what makes this opportunity special. Write 5-7 concise bullet points for key responsibilities using action verbs and specific outcomes rather than vague duties (e.g., "Develop and execute social media strategy resulting in 50% engagement increase" rather than "Manage social media"). List must-have qualifications separately from nice-to-have qualifications to avoid deterring qualified candidates who might not meet every preferred criterion. Include information about company culture, growth opportunities, and unique benefits that differentiate your organization from competitors. Optimize content for applicant tracking systems (ATS) by incorporating relevant keywords naturally throughout the posting, using standard section headers, avoiding images or graphics with text, and using common job titles that candidates search for. Ensure all language is inclusive, non-discriminatory, and compliant with employment regulations (avoid age implications, gender-specific pronouns unless relevant to role, unnecessary physical requirements, etc.). Format job posting lines according to each platform's specific requirements - some sites have character limits, required fields, or formatting restrictions. Create multiple versions if posting across different platforms with varying requirements. Submit drafts to hiring managers and HR for review and approval, incorporating feedback and making necessary revisions. Once approved, post to all designated job sites including general platforms (Indeed, LinkedIn, Glassdoor), industry-specific job boards, company career page, and any relevant professional networks or communities. Track key metrics for each posting including views, applications, application quality, and source effectiveness. Be prepared to adjust posting language, titles, or platforms based on performance data to improve candidate quality and quantity. Set up alerts or tracking systems to monitor applications and ensure timely response to candidates.

active_tasks.title: Add Comments in Manager Streams Tracking Table
steps: Access the manager streams tracking table/spreadsheet
Review recent manager streams and broadcasts
Watch or review recorded sessions for each manager
Evaluate manager performance across multiple dimensions
Assess content quality, delivery, and engagement techniques
Note specific strengths and areas for improvement
Document technical issues or production quality concerns
Analyze student/audience engagement and participation metrics
Identify best practices and successful approaches
Draft detailed, constructive comments for each manager
Include specific examples with timestamps when relevant
Add actionable recommendations for improvement
Note any training needs or support requirements
Record positive highlights and achievements
Update the tracking table with comprehensive comments
Ensure comments are professional, balanced, and helpful
Share feedback with managers individually if required
Track progress and improvements over time
resources: Training resources and best practice guides
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by accessing the centralized manager streams tracking table where all manager broadcast activities are logged. This table should include columns for manager name, stream date/time, topic covered, attendance numbers, engagement metrics, and your detailed comments section. Review the table to identify which manager streams need comment updates, prioritizing recent streams from the past week that haven't been documented yet. For each manager stream that needs review, watch the recorded session (if available) or gather information from live notes, attendance records, and engagement metrics. Create a standardized evaluation framework that assesses multiple dimensions of manager performance including: content quality and accuracy, presentation skills and delivery style, technical proficiency with streaming tools, ability to engage and interact with audience, time management and pacing, handling of questions and discussions, preparation and organization, visual aids and materials quality, energy and enthusiasm level, clarity of explanations, and professional demeanor. As you watch each stream, take detailed notes organized by these categories. Note specific timestamps for particularly strong moments or areas needing improvement (e.g., "Excellent explanation of concept at 15:30" or "Audio quality issues between 22:00-25:00"). Evaluate student/participant engagement by reviewing chat activity, questions asked, attendance duration, and any post-stream feedback or survey results. Identify patterns such as when audience engagement peaks or drops, which topics generate most interaction, and how effectively the manager responds to questions. Document technical issues comprehensively including audio/video quality problems, connectivity issues, screen sharing difficulties, platform glitches, or any technical interruptions that affected the stream quality. Note whether these were manager errors or system issues beyond their control. Recognize and document successful techniques and best practices demonstrated by each manager. These might include effective icebreakers, engaging teaching methods, creative use of polls or interactive features, excellent storytelling, real-world examples that resonate with audience, or innovative approaches to complex topics. Draft comments that are specific, constructive, and balanced. Avoid vague statements like "good job" or "needs improvement." Instead write specific observations such as: "Strong opening that immediately captured attention by relating topic to current industry trends. Consider adding more visual examples when explaining technical concepts as audience engagement dropped slightly during the theoretical section (35:00-42:00). Excellent handling of the challenging question at 1:05:00 - turned it into a great learning moment for everyone." Structure your comments to include: opening positive observation, specific areas of strength with examples, constructive suggestions for improvement with actionable steps, technical or logistical notes, overall assessment, and any support or resources that might help the manager improve. Maintain a professional, supportive tone even when addressing significant concerns. Frame feedback as opportunities for growth rather than criticism. Use language like "Consider exploring..." or "An opportunity to enhance..." rather than "You failed to..." or "This was wrong." For managers showing consistent excellence, provide specific praise and consider highlighting their streams as examples for others. Document innovative approaches or particularly effective segments that could be shared as best practices with the team. For managers struggling with specific aspects, note whether this is a one-time issue or recurring pattern. Identify whether they need additional training, technical support, mentoring, or resources. Be specific about support recommendations such as "Would benefit from training on interactive polling features" or "Might need upgraded microphone equipment for better audio quality." Ensure all comments are entered in the appropriate cells of the tracking table with consistent formatting. If the table has character limits, write full detailed comments in a separate document and include key summary points in the table with a reference to the full feedback document. Include quantitative data where available to support your qualitative observations: attendance numbers, average viewing duration, engagement rate (comments/questions per attendee), satisfaction scores if surveys were conducted, and comparison to previous streams to show improvement trends. Tag or flag streams that require immediate attention or follow-up action, such as urgent technical issues that need resolution, content concerns that need correction, or exceptional performance that should be recognized formally. If your organization has a formal feedback schedule, coordinate your comment additions with one-on-one feedback sessions with managers. Share your documented observations during these meetings, allowing for discussion and collaborative development of improvement plans. Maintain historical tracking of comments over time to identify patterns, track improvement trajectories, and provide evidence for performance evaluations. Regular review of past comments helps ensure feedback is having desired impact and managers are progressing. Set up a regular cadence for reviewing and commenting on manager streams - for example, all streams from the previous week should have detailed comments added by Monday of the following week. Consistency ensures timely feedback when experiences are still fresh. Consider creating a rating or scoring system alongside detailed comments to allow for quick visual assessment of manager performance trends over time. This could include numerical ratings for key categories (1-5 scale) plus your detailed written comments. Collaborate with other team members who may have observed the same streams to gather multiple perspectives before finalizing comments. Different observers may notice different strengths or concerns, creating more comprehensive feedback. Before finalizing all comments, review for tone and clarity. Ensure feedback is professional, constructive, specific, actionable, balanced (noting both strengths and growth areas), and free from personal bias or subjective judgments unrelated to performance. After adding comments to the tracking table, follow up with individual managers as appropriate based on your organization's feedback protocols. Some comments may be for record-keeping only, while significant concerns or exceptional performance may warrant direct conversation. Document any follow-up actions, training scheduled, or improvement plans in the tracking table alongside your comments to provide complete record of manager development journey.

Review their profile to gather context (company, role, recent activity)
Use approved messaging templates as a baseline, but personalize each message
Send message through LinkedIn (do NOT use automation tools)
Update CRM

B. Update CRM & create new company cards
 
 STEPS & INSTRUCTIONS 
- Create new company cards for any leads identified using the job sites spreadsheet but not yet added:
- Use SalesQL to gather comprehensive data (company size, industry, contact info)
- Ensure all required fields are completed accurately
Cross-reference LinkedIn profile with company website for accuracy
- Review and clean up any duplicate or incomplete entries Target: All active leads updated, 15-20 new company cards created

C. Re-engage Old Leads 

STEPS & INSTRUCTIONS 
- In LinkedIn, filter connections by date (Dec 2024 - Feb 2025) 
- Identify connections who have not been messaged recently, did not respond to initial outreach or showed initial interest but conversation stalled
- For each old connection:
Review previous conversation history to understand context
- Personalize and send re-engagement messages

### Resources and Links: 
Linkedin, message templates, CRM, Job sites spreadsheet, salesQL

LinkedIn safety measures
Messaging best practices
Account management protocols
Tool configuration requirements
- Prioritize corrections based on urgency and impact
- Implement LinkedIn Safety Protocols
 - Send follow up messages to missed leads
- Configure Google Profiles Properly
- For each lead account, verify separate Google Chrome profile exists.
- In each profile:
Install required extensions (SalesQL, any other approved tools)
Sign into correct LinkedIn account
Verify all extensions are activated and functioning
Bookmark frequently used tools and CRM
- Test each profile by performing a sample task (search, message, data lookup) Step 4: Document profile names and which LinkedIn account each manages

- Verify Workflow Alignment 
- Document current daily workflow step-by-step 
- Compare against team lead guidance 
- Identify any gaps or deviations
- Adjust workflow to match company standards 
- Share updated workflow with team lead for confirmation

google chrome, message templates, LinkedIn
